awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Intelligent Interactive Guidance System for Litigated Insurance Claims
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project enhances the efficiency, fairness, and cost-effectiveness of the United States' property and casualty insurance claims processes. This project aims to develop an advanced, artificial intelligence (AI) powered guidance system that will transform how litigated insurance claims are managed and resolved. By enhancing the decision-making process of claims professionals with automated, evidence-backed guidance, the system will significantly reduce the time and expense currently required to resolve claims, resulting in quicker payouts to claimants and decreasing the burden of legal costs. The system's innovative approach will assist in identifying critical case information, supporting claim professionals in making more informed decisions. The project has the potential to improve the overall transparency and reliability of the claims litigation processes, engendering greater trust in the insurance system. Additionally, by streamlining operations, it could lead to more efficient use of resources within the insurance industry, lowering insurance premiums for consumers and businesses. 

This SBIR Phase I project represents an opportunity to significantly improve the processing and handling of litigated insurance claims. The project’s research objectives include the development of a novel approach for information extraction from massive unstructured data collections typical in insurance claims and summarization frameworks for presenting the extracted information, enabling a concise yet comprehensive view of complex claims data. The project aims to design a visualization interface that aids understanding and facilitates more informed decision-making by claims professionals. The research applies cutting-edge AI and machine learning techniques to these objectives, expanding past the boundaries of current capabilities in data analytics within the insurance industry. The anticipated technical results include demonstrating the feasibility of this innovative system to quickly and accurately present relevant decisional information from a broad array of data, providing users with essential insights for making decisions. By improving how information is processed, summarized, and presented, the project is expected to lead to better, faster decisions in litigated insurance claims management, setting a new standard for technological applications in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Principal Investigator: James Chapman, J.D.

This project tackled one of the biggest challenges in resolving litigated insurance claims: sorting through extensive documents to uncover vital information necessary for decision making. Our team developed a prototype Intelligent Interactive Guidance System (IIGS) that leverages advanced machine learning pipelines (developing an in-house AI) to read, summarize, and organize legal and insurance documents. The goal is to help insurance professionals, attorneys, and other stakeholders quickly identify key facts, evaluate liability and damages, and make informed decisions without sifting or searching through extensive and unstructured document sets. By transforming complex and varied content into clear, structured information, the IIGS promises to reduce both the time and cost of resolving insurance disputes.

Intellectual Merit

In the technical realm, our team pushed the boundaries of how AI can learn from unstructured text. We integrated multiple techniques (like automated summarization, knowledge-graph building, and interactive question-answering) to deliver accurate, transparent results that can be traced back to the exact page or sentence in the original document. This transparency is critical for legal contexts, where stakeholders often need to verify facts and weigh evidence carefully. We also developed novel approaches to evaluate the accuracy of our system without relying on exhaustive supervised learning or manual data labeling. For example, we created a method to generate practice questions and answers directly from sample documents, making it easier to test and refine the system without relying heavily on outside experts. By merging these cutting-edge methods into a single workflow, we have advanced the field of AI for legal and insurance applications.

Broader Impacts

Although our initial target audience is insurance and legal professionals, this technology has the potential to benefit society at large. Existing legal processes can be slow and expensive, and backlogged courts make it difficult for individuals and businesses to see their cases resolved quickly. By accelerating information analysis and surfacing critical information, our system may lead to faster settlements, decreased litigation costs, and potentially fewer disputes going to trial. Streamlined resolution also frees up valuable time in the judicial system and promotes fairer access to justice.

Additionally, we laid the groundwork to handle non-text data, such as photos and videos, in later stages of development. For example, insurance professionals and attorneys often rely on images of accidents or property damage to validate claims. Integrating visual data into the IIGS could significantly expand its usefulness, giving a more holistic view of each case. Going forward, we also plan to incorporate user feedback mechanisms. When attorneys or adjusters see an answer that seems incomplete or off-target, they will be able to flag that response. Over time, these user insights will improve both the system’s accuracy and its adaptability across different types of insurance claims.

Project Results and Products

  • Prototype Software: We demonstrated a proof-of-concept system that automatically summarizes long legal documents and answers questions in plain language, complete with links to the original document passages.
  • Knowledge Graph Research: We introduced new methods for building a knowledge map that pinpoints major players (such as witnesses or experts), important dates, and key events. This map can be explored interactively, helping users visualize complex relationships.
  • Conference Presentation: Portions of the work by our team were presented at a major conference on natural language processing. By sharing our methods with the wider research community, we hope to spark more innovation in AI-driven legal tools.
  • Roadmap for Expansion: We identified the next set of challenges, such as seamlessly handling images and video, scaling up to very large datasets, and refining multi-step question answering, to be pursued in Phase II of this project.

Future Work

Software development and improvement, together with pilot deployments, are planned as we move from a proof-of-concept stage to a market-ready product. We are actively exploring partnerships with insurance companies and law firms that can pilot the system, provide feedback, and help us refine the technology for commercial use.
